clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL) Alone and ESWL Plus Endoscopy for Painful Chronic Pancreatitis
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of ESWL Alone and ESWL Combined With Endoscopic Drainage of the Main Pancreatic Duct for Painful Chronic Pancreatitis

brief_summary.textblock: Endoscopy is an established method of treatment for painful obstructive calcified pancreatitis. It involves the disintegration of calcifications using extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) followed by endoscopic removal of stone fragments possibly associated with stent insertion. A pilot study suggests that ESWL alone relieves pain in calcified chronic pancreatitis (CP). The aim of this study is to compare both techniques in a randomized controlled trial.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Painful chronic pancreatitis (>1 abdominal pain attack during the preceding 12 months)
- At least 1 calcified stone greater than 4 mm in one of its axes in the cephalic or corporeal portion of the main pancreatic duct (MPD) with upstream duct dilation
- Written informed consent obtained from the patient
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of treatment of the pancreas using ESWL, endoscopy, or surgery
- Pancreatic collection greater than 2 cm in diameter at magnetic resonance or CT scan
- Alkaline phosphatase levels greater than twice the upper limit of normal values or signs of cholangitis
- Age below 18 years
- Pregnancy or lactation
